name: Counting Arrays
description:
You are given two positive integer numbers x and y. An array F is called an
y-factorization of x iff the following conditions are met: There are y
elements in F, and all of them are integer numbers; . You have to count the
number of pairwise distinct arrays that are y-factorizations of x. Two arrays
A and B are considered different iff there exists at least one index i (1 ≤ i
≤ y) such that Ai ≠ Bi. Since the answer can be very large, print it modulo
10^9 + 7. Input The first line contains one integer q (1 ≤ q ≤ 10^5) — the
number of testcases to solve. Then q lines follow, each containing two
integers xi and yi (1 ≤ xi, yi ≤ 10^6). Each of these lines represents a
testcase. Output Print q integers. i-th integer has to be equal to the number
of yi-factorizations of xi modulo 10^9 + 7. Example Input 2 6 3 4 2 Output 36
6 Note In the second testcase of the example there are six y-factorizations: 
- 4, - 1;  - 2, - 2;  - 1, - 4; 1, 4; 2, 2; 4, 1.
